channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Venezuelan Court: Chávez Swearing-In Can Be Postponed
item.description: Amid heated debate between the Venezuelan government and the opposition, the country’s Supreme Court ruled that President Hugo Chávez can be sworn in after Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: The Lede Blog: Saudi Arabia Executes Sri Lankan Maid
item.description: A Sri Lankan woman who was employed as a domestic worker in Saudi Arabia was beheaded by the Saudi authorities after she was accused of murdering an infant in her charge and then sentenced to death.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Iranian Captives Freed in Major Prisoner Exchange in Syria
item.description: More than 2,000 prisoners held by the Syrian authorities were being released in return for 48 Iranians held by rebels for months, Turkish and Iranian news reports said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Iranians released by Syrian rebels arrived at a hotel in Damascus on Wednesday.

item.title: In Old Taliban Strongholds, Qualms About What Lies Ahead
item.description: Peace has eased safety concerns in Helmand Province, but there is little faith in the Afghan government’s ability to maintain the security gains won by American and British troops.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Aid Groups Report Rising Misery Among Displaced Syrians
item.description: The United Nations said it was unable to feed a million hungry residents and aid agencies reported an outbreak of violence in a refugee camp in Jordan.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on Tuesday at the Zaatari camp in Jordan, where violence followed heavy rains.

item.title: Delegation to North Korea Urges More Access to Internet and Cellphones
item.description: The group, which includes Google’s executive chairman and Bill Richardson, a former governor of New Mexico, also called on North Korea to put a moratorium on missile launchings.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Obama Nominees in Step on Light Footprint
item.description: President Obama’s selection of a new national security team appears to have ended, at least for now, many of the internal debates about military interventions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama named John O. Brennan, right, as his choice for C.I.A. director and chose Chuck Hagel, left, to be his next defense secretary.

item.title: Global Update: China Moves to Prevent Spread of Yellow Fever From Africa
item.description: As many Chinese citizens now work in Africa, Chinese officials have urged health authorities to check for fevers in people arriving from the continent.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Record Heat Fuels Widespread Fires in Australia
item.description: An unprecedented heat wave has sparked raging bushfires across some of the country’s most populated regions, pushing firefighters to their limits.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:description: A firefighter fought to save a property threatened by the Dean's Gully fire near Wandandian, south of Nowra, New South Wales on Tuesday.

item.title: Online Banking Attacks Were Work of Iran, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The skill required to execute the attacks convinced American officials that Iran was behind them, likely in retaliation for economic sanctions and online attacks by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH and QUENTIN HARDY

item.title: The Lede Blog: The Scent of Supreme Leadership
item.description: The Washington Post's man in Tehran, Jason Rezaian, has discovered the perfect gift for pious Iranians who like to smoke in their cars: an air freshener in the image of Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Anti-Semitism Charge Provokes Furor in Germany
item.description: An anti-Semitism watchdog has provoked a storm by including a prominent German journalist in a list of leading anti-Semites. His defenders insist criticism of Israel does not equate with hatred of Jews.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Berlin's Holocaust memorial pictured in the snow on Dec 12.

item.title: Chinese Officials Pledge to Loosen Controls Over Embattled Newspaper
item.description: The deal appeared to bring a tentative peace to Southern Weekend’s newsroom, as another Chinese newspaper faced a crisis on Wednesday over the forced publishing of an editorial.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD

item.title: Contractor Settles Case in Iraq Prison Abuse
item.description: The American contractor, hired by the military to provide translation services, has agreed to pay a total of $5 million to scores of detainees at the Abu Ghraib prison.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

item.title: Chinese Thirst for Safe Baby Formula Empties Australian Shelves
item.description: The run on sales of infant formula in Australia is being blamed on Chinese visitors who are believed to be buying in bulk and carrying it home any way they can manage.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Japan Summons China’s Envoy Over Disputed Islands
item.description: The Japanese deputy foreign minister is said to have strongly protested the 13-hour incursion by four Chinese surveillance ships near uninhabited islands also claimed by China and Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Wolf Population Draws Hunters in Siberia
item.description: Officials in the Sakha-Yakutia region of Siberia have gone so far as to declare a state of emergency to draw attention to the wolves eating livestock, including horses and reindeer.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Activist’s Convicted in Vietnam Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: A Vietnamese court on Wednesday convicted 14 democracy activists of plotting to overthrow the government and sentenced them to jail terms ranging from 3 to 13 years.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SETH MYDANS
item.media:credit: Nguyen Van Nhat/Vietnam News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Democracy activists convicted of plotting to overthrow the Vietnamese government were sentenced to jail terms on Wednesday at a court in Nghe An province.

item.title: Private Manning of WikiLeaks Case Must Face Charges
item.description: But the military judge in the case said that the conditions under which the former Army intelligence analyst Pfc. Bradley E. Manning was held were improperly harsh at times.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Pfc. Bradley Manning, a former Army intelligence analyst, on Tuesday. His court-martial is scheduled to begin on March 6.

item.title: In Clashes in Kashmir, Indians Claim 2 Soldiers Were Killed
item.description: The sudden surge in violence between Indians and Pakistanis is a troubling development in Kashmir, where a cease-fire has been in place for almost 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Jan. 9
item.description: A protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: British Soldier Killed by Afghan Soldier
item.description: The Taliban claimed responsibility for arranging the infiltration into the Afghan Army of the soldier responsible for Monday’s shooting.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: U.S. Is Open to Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
item.description: On the eve of a visit by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it was open to a so-called zero option when the NATO combat mission there ends.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Chinese Man Pleads Guilty in Copyright Violation Case
item.description: Xiang Li sold more than 2,000 pirated software products worth more than $100 million, prosecutors say.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW MARTIN

item.title: South Africa Police Fire Rubber Bullets at Farm Worker Protest
item.description: Police tried to disperse hundreds of the striking workers in South Africa’s prime grape-growing region on Wednesday after a protest for higher wages turned violent.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
